data.title: Test: Command Palette improvements
data.body:
- [x] win - @ramya-rao-a    
- [x] mac - @aefernandes 
- [x] linux - @joaomoreno 

Complexity: 2
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13080 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17163

The command palette got some new features and UX updates.

**UX**
* verify you see keybindings now represented in the same way as they show up in the keybindings editor

**Preserve Input**
* verify a new setting `workbench.commandPalette.preserveInput` can be used to let it restore the previous typed input when opened (only when you open via the `workbench.action.showCommands` command, which is `Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+P`)
* this input will be reset once you restart (e.g. not persisted)
* verify you see the entire input value being selected so that typing just removes it (except for the leading ">")

**MRU**
We now show the most recently used commands on top of the other commands (similar to how we show most recently opened files in the files picker)
* verify that the most recently used command always shows to the top
* verify that when you start typing you see the MRU list as well as the other commands sorted and the most recently used commands always stay at the top
* verify you are not seeing the same command in the MRU list and the other category
* verify the number of entries is limited via the setting `workbench.commandPalette.history`
* verify that you can disable this feature via setting `workbench.commandPalette.history: 0`

data.title: ConfigurationResolver is not multi-root fit
data.body:
We seem to have variables support via the [configuration resolver](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/configurationResolver/node/configurationResolverService.ts#L20), specifically:
* `cwd`
* `workspaceRoot`
* `workspaceRootFolderName`
* `relativeFile`

In a multi root environment we need to change this single root assumption. I think there are two options:
* if the configuration file is actually originating from a folder within the workspace we could set that folder as the "workspace root"
* otherwise we shoud probably just pick the workspace from the last editor that was opened that has a workspace associated. for that I added `IHistoryService.getLastActiveWorkspaceRoot()`

/cc @weinand @dbaeumer

data.title: Debug: make launching multi root folder aware
data.body:
Today we seem to collect the launch.json from the single root workspace here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugConfigurationManager.ts#L345

In a multi root environment we need to change this assumption. There are a couple of options:
* just take the first folders configuration and show the others from a picker (e.g. add a "More..." command to the debug dropdown which opens a picker)
* track the active file and then use that files workspace as default when checking for the config file (there is `IHistoryService.getLastActiveWorkspaceRoot()` to help out)
* just treat all folders the same and collect configs from all folders and merge them into one list

data.title: Multi root: Use new emmet to avoid single workspace dependency
data.body:
It looks like we are looking for emmet specific configuration files inside the workspace: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/emmet/electron-browser/emmetActions.ts#L289

This will not work anymore once we are in a multi root environment. I am not sure what the configuration is for but you probably need to read it per workspace root and then support it based on from which file the emmet action is executed.

data.title: #23797 git manage ignore files
data.body: Adding feature to #23797

data.title: Multi root support for extensions management
data.body:
## Workspace recommendations
Today we scan for a `extensions.json` inside the workspace `.vscode` folder: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/extensions/browser/extensionsActions.ts#L1227 and also here https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/extensions/electron-browser/extensionTipsService.ts#L71

This does not work in a multi root environment. I think we should instead go over all root folders and collect all extensions that are recommended.

## Workspace disabled extensions

data.title: Add option to disable git indicators in gutter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1767466/27417830-05d5b982-56cc-11e7-9ba2-da5d995bfe29.png)

I would like to be able to disable seeing these green/blue lines in the gutter for where I've changed code. As far as I can tell, this can only be done by turning off `git.enabled`. That seems unfortunate, as I think one of the editors strengths is it's source control/diffing view, and I'd like not to lose that.

data.title: TextEditorEdit does not handle and convert \r and \r\n as the documentation states
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Summary of issue:
I am trying to use TextEditorEdit replace to replace random text with text including newlines. The newline characters are literally inserted instead of converting to line breaks.


From the docs it specifically says if I pass in \n or \r\n they will be normalized:
```
	export interface TextEditorEdit {
		/**
		 * Replace a certain text region with a new value.
		 * You can use \r\n or \n in `value` and they will be normalized to the current [document](#TextDocument).
		 *
		 * @param location The range this operation should remove.
		 * @param value The new text this operation should insert after removing `location`.
		 */
		replace(location: Position | Range | Selection, value: string): void;
```

Steps to Reproduce:

Using this function, I pass in a valid range and the text is ```abc\nabc\nabc```

```
    static async replace(range: vscode.Range, text: string): Promise<boolean> {
    return vscode.window.activeTextEditor!.edit(editBuilder => {
      editBuilder.replace(new vscode.Selection(range.end, range.start), text);
    });
  }

```

I end up with ```abc\nabc\abc\n``` in the editor instead of this:

```
abc
abc
abc
```

data.title: When editting multiple occurences(Ctrl+F2), pressing end causes cursor to be out of sync in some cases
data.body:
Do you have a question? Please ask it on [Stack Overflow with `vscode` tag](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode)

(Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these)
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create sample file:
Hello
Hello
/*Hello*/
2. Put cursor after 'H' and press ctrl+F2
3. Press end button.

Notice that the cursor for the 3rd line (commented out Hello) goes to the end (after '/'). This makes it difficult to rename all occurences of "Hello" when accidentally pressing end because the cursor is out of place for items like in line 3 above.

data.title: Wrap tasks cmds as Actions for telemetry
data.body:
- previously, we were unable to tell if cmds like `workbench.action.tasks.runTask` were accessed from the menu
- `Action` has automatic telemetry that adds a 'from' dimension that tells us where it was run
- thus, I wrapped the task commands as `Action` and called those at the task top-level menu

/cc @dbaeumer

data.body:
- Open search viewlet
- Put cursor in include/exclude box
- Press enter
- Now search text field is focused. It shouldn't take focus from the include/exclude boxes

data.title: Test: Atom Keymap Version 3
data.body:
**Complexity:** 2

**OS:**
- [x] any - @rebornix 

**Background**
Version 3 update to the Atom keymap changes settings for the users of the extension. We want to do this without disrupting their flow. 

**Tests**
1. Install the extension from the [vsix](https://github.com/waderyan/vscode-atom-keybindings/blob/master/atom-keybindings-3.0.0.vsix)
2. Confirm the version three prompt shows 
3. Click Yes. Confirm that new settings are added. Try one of the settings to confirm it works as expected (ex. multi cursor with cmd or ctrl). 
4. Remove all the settings. Reload VS Code. 
5. See the prompt and click no. Confirm a setting indicating the prompt showed was added and that other settings were not added. 
6. Reload VS Code. Confirm the prompt does not show again.

data.title: Don't show recommended workspace extensions message if all are enabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create `extensions.json`
2. Add an enabled extension (e.g `eg2.tslint`)
3. Restart vscode
4. _Workspace has recommended extensions_ message appears

If a user already has all the recommended workspace extensions installed and enabled, they don't need to access the marketplace to install them - only if the extensions are disabled or not installed

Selecting `Don't show again` isn't ideal, as you wont get notified when extensions you don't have are added

Edit: `Don't show again` is also a global setting and not per workspace and appears to be irreversible
